answers.text: Out of more than 5.8 million votes for the two main contenders Bush and Al Gore, around 500 votes separated the two candidates

qas.question: How severe is Florida's Disenfranchisement law

answers.text: Florida's felony disenfranchisement law is more severe than most European nations or other American states

qas.question: What did this mean in the 2000 election

answers.text: if the state’s 827,000 disenfranchised felons had voted at the same rate as other Floridians, Democratic candidate Al Gore would have won Florida

plausible_answers.text: the state played a pivotal role

qas.question: How many votes did Al Gore win by?

context: In the closely contested 2000 election, <b3_0>the state played a pivotal role<b3_0/>. <a0_0>Out of more than 5.8 million votes for the two main contenders <b4_0>Bush and Al Gore<b4_0/>, around 500 votes separated the two candidates<a0_0/> for the all-decisive Florida electoral votes that landed Bush the election win. <a1_0>Florida's felony disenfranchisement law is more severe than most European nations or other American states<a1_0/>. A 2002 study in the American Sociological Review concluded that "<a2_0>if the state’s <b7_0>827,000<b7_0/> <b6_0>disenfranchised felons<b6_0/> had voted at the same rate as other Floridians, Democratic candidate Al Gore would have won Florida<a2_0/>—and the presidency—by more than <b5_0>80,000<b5_0/> votes."
